body: All the remotes give size on directory listing anyway so speed-wise this would be the same as `--size-only`.

i don't know why you say that the --size-only has the same speed. It isn't true!
Using cloudberry trial or swift commadnline i can obtain the listing of all my 5 tb in 30 sec and there are 700k files. 
using rclone with --size-only it took 45 minutes last night only for 40k files.

You are wrong when you say that the speed is the same. Please check your code or do some tests!
If you would like me to reproduce your results then please post the command lines you used - thanks!

Here is an example showing that a `--size-only` sync is quick with a swift backend.

```
$ rclone --dry-run --size-only sync local swift:Images
2015/11/09 20:44:52 Swift container Images: Building file list
2015/11/09 20:45:05 Swift container Images: Waiting for checks to finish
2015/11/09 20:45:06 Swift container Images: Waiting for transfers to finish
2015/11/09 20:45:06 Waiting for deletions to finish

Transferred:            0 Bytes (   0.00 kByte/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:             58159
Transferred:          404
Elapsed time:       14.2s
```

And without `--size-only`

```
$ rclone --dry-run sync local swift:Images
2015/11/09 20:47:19 Swift container Images: Building file list
[snip]
2015/11/09 20:53:59 Swift container Images: Waiting for transfers to finish
2015/11/09 20:53:59 Waiting for deletions to finish

Transferred:            0 Bytes (   0.00 kByte/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:             58159
Transferred:          404
Elapsed time:     6m40.1s
```

I have the same commands but with copy and not sync. I will try with sync but i wouldn't delete any files

> Il giorno 09 nov 2015, alle ore 9:59 PM, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com ha scritto:

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Can you post the actual commands with output  like I did above.  You can use `--dry-run` like I did so no transfers or deletions actually happen. Doing it with `copy` is fine.

Could you also post the result of running `rclone size` on the container too please (along with times).

I killed the process after 14 mins
Can you try that with `--dump-headers` and see if you can work out what is happening?
Can you also try `rclone size "hubic:default/newworks"` please? And post the results. Thanks!

i'll do the tests in the following minutes.
However, yesterday night i set up a little python script. It does exactly what i wanted.
1) create a local files list with sizes excluding folders
2) create a remote local list with sizes excludin folders
3) checking and correcting size of 0byte files if they have the manifest
4) give results

I can check and compare 300k files in less than a minute. So it's definitely an rclone issue.

Here the code. Sorry, no comments. I wrote it fast

> https://gist.githubusercontent.com/xgiovio/9e3eed6032c91efa064e/raw/57e33908391a8fcc7a4a3ceeba82d45bbf11c764/test.py

> Can you try that with --dump-headers and see if you can work out what is happening?

done, it send http requests on each folder. I think they are 0 files folder. it should skip these, checking the content type application/folder returned by directory listing

> Can you also try rclone size "hubic:default/newworks" please? And post the results. Thanks!

Done. Exactly the same situazion. It's slow because using --dump-headers i can see http requests on each folder.

I think you should only filters these 0bytes folder like the bug in past days on folders created by hubic

rename.to: swift: Use Content-Type from directory listing to avoid lookups on 0 byte files in listings

body:
OK I think we are getting there!  What you are saying is that 0 byte files that hubic uses to mark directores are causing an HTTP request.

I can see why that is, and yes, I'm ignoring the content type in the listing.

I should be able to fix that relatively easily.

issue.title: slow time getting lists for files - also using checkers

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
hello,
listing directory should use content-length only for 0 files with manifest metadata (large objects)

For normal objects i don't understand why rclone use 8 default checkers to obtain files list.

using the python command line 

> swift list -l container_name/path

 you can have an immediate list of all files with relative sizes. Only the reported sizes for large objects are wrong and should be grabbed checking the content-length metadata.

Am i wrong? thank you

body: yes perfect. it can be a good bug fix for 1.25 milestone. (;
any news on the release? i would like to try the fix on the nas. could you send me a 1.25 compiled for arm? thank you

This fix has gone live in v1.25

Please test it and if you find any problems then open a new issue.

Thanks

Nick
